options.label: C
options.text: By providing background information and context

options.label: D
options.text: By using dialogue to convey emotions

title: What is society? | US society for children

multiple-choice.question: What is a society?

options.label: A
options.text: A small group of people who live close to each other.

options.label: B
options.text: A large group of people who share the same laws, rights, and resources.

options.label: C
options.text: A group of people who only speak the same language.

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people who only belong to the same cultural community.

multiple-choice.question: Can people in a society live far away from each other?

options.label: A
options.text: No, they must live close by.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, they can live far away from each other.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if they speak the same language.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if they belong to the same cultural community.

multiple-choice.question: What do the Lopez family in Texas and the Wilson family in Maine have in common?

options.label: A
options.text: They live in the same neighborhood.

options.label: C
options.text: They are part of the same cultural community.

options.label: D
options.text: They are all members of American society.

multiple-choice.question: What are some things that members of American society share?

options.label: C
options.text: The same flag, voting rights, and leadership.

multiple-choice.question: Can a society be a group of people who do the same type of work?

options.label: A
options.text: No, it can only be a group of people who live close by.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, it can be a group of people who do the same type of work.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if they speak the same language.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if they belong to the same cultural community.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a society based on a shared interest or goal?

options.label: A
options.text: A group of people who live in the same neighborhood.

options.label: B
options.text: A group of doctors who work at the same hospital.

options.label: C
options.text: A group of animal protection volunteers.

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people who only speak the same language.

multiple-choice.question: Do members of a society have to work or volunteer at the same place?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, they must work or volunteer at the same place.

options.label: B
options.text: No, they can work or volunteer at different places.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if they speak the same language.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if they belong to the same cultural community.

multiple-choice.question: What is something that the people around you, near and far, can be considered?
Can people in a society have different cultural backgrounds?

options.label: A
options.text: No, they must have the same cultural background.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, they can have different cultural backgrounds.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if they speak the same language.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if they live in the same neighborhood.

multiple-choice.question: Can people in a society speak different languages?

options.label: A
options.text: No, they must speak the same language.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, they can speak different languages.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if they belong to the same cultural community.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if they live in the same neighborhood.

title: Which is better: Soap or hand sanitizer? - Alex Rosenthal and Pall Thordarson

multiple-choice.question: What are the two simple ways to prevent a virus from infecting you through your hands?

options.label: B
options.text: Using soap and water, and hand sanitizer

options.label: C
options.text: Avoiding touching your face and washing your clothes

options.label: D
options.text: Using a disinfectant spray and wipes

multiple-choice.question: What is the structure of the outer surface of the coronavirus that causes COVID-19?
How do soap molecules (amphiphiles) work to break down the coronavirus's shell?

options.label: A
options.text: They compete with the lipids for space and break up the regularity of the virus's membrane

options.label: B
options.text: They form a protective barrier around the virus

options.label: C
options.text: They attract the lipids and hold them together

options.label: D
options.text: They repel the lipids and push them away

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of hand sanitizers on the coronavirus's membrane?

options.label: A
options.text: It strengthens the bonds within the membrane

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on the membrane

options.label: C
options.text: It makes the hydrophobic effect disappear and gives the molecules room to move around

options.label: D
options.text: It forms a protective barrier around the virus

multiple-choice.question: Why do doctors recommend washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it takes that long to kill the virus

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the intricate landscape of your hand and the need to get soap everywhere

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's more convenient than using hand sanitizer

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's more effective than hand sanitizer

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of using soap and water over hand sanitizer?

options.label: A
options.text: It's more convenient to use on the go

options.label: B
options.text: It's more effective at killing the virus

options.label: C
options.text: It washes away any dirt that could hide virus particles and is easier to fully cover your hands

options.label: D
options.text: It's less expensive than hand sanitizer

multiple-choice.question: What is a common problem in many communities during a coronavirus outbreak?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of access to hand sanitizer

options.label: B
options.text: Lack of access to clean drinking water

options.label: C
options.text: Lack of access to medical care

multiple-choice.question: How do rhinoviruses (common cold viruses) differ from coronaviruses?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a lipid membrane instead of a capsid

options.label: B
options.text: They have a capsid instead of a lipid membrane

options.label: C
options.text: They are more easily killed by soap and water

options.label: D
options.text: They are more easily killed by hand sanitizer

multiple-choice.question: When might hand sanitizer be more effective than soap and water?

options.label: A
options.text: When dealing with a coronavirus outbreak

options.label: B
options.text: When dealing with a rhinovirus outbreak

options.label: C
options.text: When soap and water are not available

multiple-choice.question: What is the best way to know which method to use (soap and water or hand sanitizer) during a viral outbreak?

options.label: A
options.text: Follow the advice of accredited medical professionals

options.label: B
options.text: Use your own judgment and do what feels right

options.label: C
options.text: Follow the advice of friends and family

options.label: D
options.text: Use the internet to research and decide

title: The Princess and the Pea - Read aloud picture book

multiple-choice.question: What was the prince searching for in his travels around the world?

options.label: A
options.text: A beautiful castle to live in.

options.label: B
options.text: A brave knight to be his companion.

multiple-choice.question: Why was the prince unhappy when he returned home from his travels?

options.label: A
options.text: He had not found a beautiful castle to live in.

options.label: B
options.text: He had not found a brave knight to be his companion.

options.label: C
options.text: He had not found a real princess to marry.

options.label: D
options.text: He had not found a magical kingdom to rule.

multiple-choice.question: What happened on the evening the princess arrived at the castle?

options.label: A
options.text: A grand feast was held in her honor.

options.label: B
options.text: A terrible storm struck with thunder, lightning, and rain.

options.label: C
options.text: A beautiful rainbow appeared in the sky.

options.label: D
options.text: A magical spell was cast on the castle.

multiple-choice.question: What did the old queen do to test whether the princess was real?

options.label: A
options.text: She asked the princess to cook a meal for the king.

options.label: B
options.text: She asked the princess to sing a song for the prince.

options.label: C
options.text: She placed a pea under 20 mattresses and 20 feather beds for the princess to sleep on.

options.label: D
options.text: She asked the princess to dance a waltz with the king.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the queen and king believe the princess was real?

options.label: A
options.text: She had beautiful hair and clothes.

options.label: B
options.text: She had a kind heart and a gentle smile.

options.label: C
options.text: She had felt the pea through 20 mattresses and 20 feather beds.

options.label: D
options.text: She had brought a large dowry to the castle.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the pea after the princess passed the test?

options.label: A
options.text: It was thrown away in the castle garden.

options.label: B
options.text: It was put in the royal museum.

options.label: C
options.text: It was given to the prince as a keepsake.

options.label: D
options.text: It was lost in the castle corridors.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the prince ask the princess to marry him?

options.label: A
options.text: He loved her beautiful hair and clothes.

options.label: B
options.text: He admired her kind heart and gentle smile.

options.label: C
options.text: He believed she was a real princess.

options.label: D
options.text: He wanted to inherit her kingdom.

multiple-choice.question: What was the condition of the princess when she arrived at the castle?
How many mattresses and feather beds did the queen place on top of the pea?
What was the outcome of the prince's search for a real princess?

options.label: A
options.text: He never found a real princess.

options.label: B
options.text: He found a real princess, but she refused to marry him.

options.label: C
options.text: He found a real princess and married her.

options.label: D
options.text: He gave up his search and became a monk.

title: The sentence song

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It is a letter that is only used in questions.

multiple-choice.question: What punctuation marks can be used to end a sentence?

options.label: A

options.label: C

options.text: To signify the end of a statement.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a sentence?

options.label: B
options.text: It ends with a period, exclamation, or question mark.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using an exclamation mark at the end of a sentence?

options.label: C
options.text: To signify the end of a statement.

options.text: To clean and oxygenate the seafloor.

title: Can you trust your eyes?

multiple-choice.question: How do we know what we're seeing is real, and can we really trust our eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: Our eyes can always be trusted to show us reality.

options.label: B
options.text: Our brain interprets what we see, so we can't always trust our eyes.

options.label: C
options.text: We can only trust our eyes in certain situations.

options.label: D
options.text: It's impossible to know what's real and what's not.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you introduce colors to the two grey rectangular columns illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: The columns appear as different colors.

options.label: B
options.text: The columns appear as the same color.

options.label: C
options.text: The columns appear as different shades of grey.

options.label: D
options.text: The columns appear as the same shade of grey.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Munker-White illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: An optical illusion where two colors appear different due to surrounding imagery.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you remove the surrounding imagery from the checkerboard illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: Tile A appears darker than tile B.

options.label: B
options.text: Tile A appears lighter than tile B.

options.label: C
options.text: Tile A and tile B appear as the same color.

options.label: D
options.text: Tile A and tile B appear as different colors.

multiple-choice.question: Why do our brains judge color and brightness in context?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide us with an absolute color or physical property of our external reality.

options.label: B
options.text: To interpret what we see as efficiently as possible in order to interact with the environment most appropriately.

options.label: C
options.text: To trick us into seeing things that aren't there.

options.label: D
options.text: To make us question our perception of reality.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of our senses, specifically our eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide us with an absolute color or physical property of our external reality.

options.label: B
options.text: To interpret what we see as efficiently as possible in order to interact with the environment most appropriately.

options.label: C
options.text: To see the world in black and white.

options.label: D
options.text: To see the world in slow motion.

multiple-choice.question: How does the tile illusion take advantage of our brain's interpretation of color and brightness?

options.label: A
options.text: By making objects appear darker in shadows.

options.label: B
options.text: By making objects appear lighter in shadows.

options.label: C
options.text: By making objects appear the same color in shadows.

options.label: D
options.text: By making objects appear different colors in shadows.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you remove the background gradient from the middle bar illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: The bar appears as a different color.

options.label: B
options.text: The bar appears as the same color.

options.label: C
options.text: The bar appears as a gradient.

options.label: D
options.text: The bar appears as a solid color.

multiple-choice.question: Why does our perception of the bar's color change when the background gradient is removed?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our brains are tricked into seeing a different color.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our brains compare the surrounding environment to create our perception.

options.label: C
options.text: Because our brains can't distinguish between different colors.

options.label: D
options.text: Because our brains can't distinguish between different shades of grey.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the video?

options.label: A
options.text: That our eyes can always be trusted to show us reality.

options.label: B
options.text: That our brain interprets what we see, so we can't always trust our eyes.

options.label: C
options.text: That optical illusions are just tricks of the mind.

options.label: D
options.text: That color and brightness are absolute properties of our external reality.

title: Fun cartoon on Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. for Kids!

multiple-choice.question: What was Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s profession?

options.label: A
options.text: American Baptist minister, activist, and politician.

options.label: B
options.text: American Baptist minister, activist, and humanitarian.

multiple-choice.question: Where was Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. born?
What was Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birth name?
Why did Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s father change his name?

options.label: A
options.text: He was impressed by the theologian Martin Luther during a trip to Germany.

options.label: B
options.text: He wanted to give his son a more meaningful name.

options.label: C
options.text: He wanted to change his name to something more American.

options.label: D
options.text: He was forced to change his name by the government.

multiple-choice.question: At what age did Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. enter Morehouse College?
Where did Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. meet his wife Coretta Scott?
What event sparked Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s involvement in the civil rights movement?
What was the name of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s famous speech during the March on Washington?
What award did Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. receive in 1964?
When was Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. assassinated?

title: Frederick Douglass for kids (cartoon biography)

multiple-choice.question: What was Frederick Douglass's occupation, and what was he known for?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a slave owner who was against the abolition of slavery.

options.label: B
options.text: He was an abolitionist who wanted to stop slavery and spoke out against people who used African Americans as slaves.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a president who helped end the Civil War.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a sailor who traveled the world.

multiple-choice.question: Why was it against the law for slaves to read during the time of slavery in America?

options.label: A
options.text: Because slave owners thought reading was a waste of time.

options.label: B
options.text: Because slave owners wanted to keep slaves from gaining knowledge and becoming educated.

options.label: C
options.text: Because slave owners thought reading was only for white people.

options.label: D
options.text: Because slave owners thought reading would make slaves lazy.

multiple-choice.question: How did Frederick Douglass learn to read?

options.label: A
options.text: A slave owner's wife taught him the basics of reading.

options.label: B
options.text: He went to school with white children.

options.label: C
options.text: He taught himself by watching other white children learn in school.

options.label: D
options.text: He was born knowing how to read.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Frederick Douglass when his master found out he was teaching other slaves to read?

options.label: A
options.text: His master was proud of him and gave him a reward.

options.label: B
options.text: His master was angry and beat him.

options.label: C
options.text: His master was indifferent and didn't care.

options.label: D
options.text: His master was surprised and asked him to teach him too.

multiple-choice.question: How did Frederick Douglass escape to the North?

options.label: A
options.text: He walked for miles until he reached the North.

options.label: B
options.text: He borrowed the papers of a free sailor and used them to escape.

options.label: C
options.text: He was helped by a group of abolitionists.

options.label: D
options.text: He used a map to navigate his way to the North.

multiple-choice.question: What did Frederick Douglass write that told about his life experiences?
Why did Frederick Douglass have to escape to Britain?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he wanted to see the world.

options.label: B
options.text: Because he was afraid his master would come and capture him.

options.label: C
options.text: Because he wanted to meet new people.

options.label: D
options.text: Because he wanted to learn a new language.

multiple-choice.question: Which president did Frederick Douglass advise?
What did Frederick Douglass convince President Lincoln to do?

options.label: A
options.text: To give more freedom to slave owners.

options.label: B
options.text: To give more weapons to African Americans to help fight with the Union soldiers.

options.label: C
options.text: To end the Civil War immediately.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Frederick Douglass continue to speak out against slavery and the poor treatment of African Americans?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he wanted to be famous.

options.label: B
options.text: Because he wanted to live a free life.

options.label: C
options.text: Because he couldn't accept living a free life while others were being treated poorly.

options.label: D
options.text: Because he wanted to be a leader.

title: Watch this educational video for children with a Rosa Parks biography

multiple-choice.question: When was Rosa Parks born?
Why did Rosa Parks' parents decide not to live together when she was a kid?

options.label: A
options.text: The transcript does not mention the reason.

options.label: B
options.text: They were too young to take care of Rosa.

options.label: C
options.text: They were too old to take care of Rosa.

options.label: D
options.text: They did not have enough money to support Rosa.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the group that Rosa's grandfather protected their farm from?

options.label: A
options.text: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP)

multiple-choice.question: Why did Rosa Parks leave school in the 11th grade?

options.label: B
options.text: She wanted to get a job.

options.label: C
options.text: She wanted to help her sick mom and grandmother.

options.label: D
options.text: She was forced to leave school.

multiple-choice.question: What organization was Rosa Parks' husband, Raymond Parks, a part of?

options.label: A
options.text: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP)

multiple-choice.question: What event on December 1, 1955, sparked a change for how African Americans were treated in the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: Rosa Parks got her high school degree.

options.label: C
options.text: Rosa Parks refused to move from her seat on the bus.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Montgomery Boycott?

options.label: A
options.text: The city decided to treat African Americans more unfairly.

options.label: B
options.text: The city decided to keep the segregation laws.

options.label: C
options.text: The city had to change the segregation laws.

options.label: D
options.text: The city did not do anything.

multiple-choice.question: When did the Montgomery Boycott officially end?
What was the Supreme Court's decision regarding the segregation laws?

options.label: A
options.text: They decided to keep the segregation laws.

options.label: B
options.text: They decided to make the segregation laws stricter.

options.label: C
options.text: They decided that the segregation laws were unfair.

options.label: D
options.text: They did not make a decision.

multiple-choice.question: When did Rosa Parks die?

title: Learn to read | Phonics for kids | Long vowels - OU and OY

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the ranch mentioned in the story?
What is the main task of a cowboy in the story?
What does the cowboy ask the two buckaroos to do to help him?

options.label: C
options.text: To help him round up a cow

multiple-choice.question: What does the cowboy say the two buckaroos need to do to be cowboys?

options.label: A
options.text: They need to ride a horse

options.label: B
options.text: They need to rope a steer

options.label: C
options.text: They need to look like cowboys and walk like cowboys

multiple-choice.question: What sound do the cowboy and the two buckaroos hear while searching for a cow?
How many cows does the cowboy have at the beginning of the story?
How many cows does the cowboy need to round up?
What does the cowboy say after he and the two buckaroos round up one cow?

options.label: B
options.text: "Good job, friends! One cow rounded up, 999 cows to go!"

multiple-choice.question: What is the cowboy's reaction when he finally rounds up 1000 cows?
What is the tone of the story?

title: 6 ways to start a sentence | Sentence structure | Learn to write

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the best ways to start a sentence?

options.label: C
options.text: By putting the subject first and the verb second

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of a verb in a sentence?

options.label: B
options.text: To tell the reader where something is happening

options.label: C
options.text: To tell the reader what the subject is doing

multiple-choice.question: How can you start a sentence to provide more information about the location of an event?

options.label: A
options.text: By using words that tell you when something is happening

options.label: B
options.text: By using words that tell you where something is happening

options.label: C
options.text: By using words that tell you who is involved

options.label: D
options.text: By using words that tell you why something is happening

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of starting a sentence with a question?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide more information about the subject

multiple-choice.question: What type of phrase can you use to start a sentence that describes an action?
What type of word can you use to start a sentence that describes a state of being?
Why is it important to use a comma when starting a sentence with an -ing or -ed word?

options.label: A
options.text: To separate the subject from the verb

options.label: B
options.text: To separate the independent clause from the dependent clause

options.label: C
options.text: To indicate a pause in the sentence

options.label: D
options.text: To set off the introductory phrase

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using an -ly word to start a sentence?

options.label: D
options.text: To describe the manner in which something is done

multiple-choice.question: How can you make writing less scary?

options.label: C
options.text: By adding variety to your sentence structure

options.label: D
options.text: By avoiding the use of adverbs

multiple-choice.question: Why is it a good idea to add different sentence starters to your writing plan?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure that you use only simple sentences

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure that you use only complex sentences

options.label: C
options.text: To remind you to use a variety of sentence structures

options.label: D
options.text: To avoid the use of adverbs

title: Learn to read | Phonics for kids | Long U Vowels

multiple-choice.question: What does it mean to be a Native American?

options.label: A
options.text: That you were among the largest group of people living in the United States of America.

options.label: B
options.text: That you are among the most important groups of people living in the United States of America.

options.label: C
options.text: That you were one of the original people who lived in the United States of America.

options.label: D
options.text: That you were one of the founding fathers of the United States of America.

multiple-choice.question: There are more than 500 Native American tribes and nations. Which 5 tribes were mentioned in the video?

options.label: A
options.text: Apache, Cherokee, Iroquois, Navajo, and Sioux

options.label: B
options.text: Cherokee, Anasazi, Chippewa, Pawnee, and Osage

options.label: C
options.text: Apache, Iroquois, Chippewa, Pawnee, and Lakota

options.label: D
options.text: Navajo, Sioux, Lakota, Pawnee, and Osage

multiple-choice.question: What does the tribe name Cherokee mean?
What is a "wigwam"?

options.label: A
options.text: A farming technique that increases crops.

options.label: B
options.text: A shelter built from branches, leaves, and grass.

options.label: C
options.text: A shelter built from mud bricks and clay.

options.label: D
options.text: A fishing technique that used a spear.

multiple-choice.question: What were the Native Americans of the Sioux tribe known for?
Which region did the Navajo tribe originally live in?
What were the Native Americans of the Iroquois tribe known for?
What is another word for "agriculture"?
How many Native American tribes and nations are there today?
What were the five tribal names that the students were asked to find in the word search?

options.label: A
options.text: Cherokee, Sioux, Navajo, Iroquois, and Apache.

options.label: B
options.text: Cherokee, Anasazi, Chippewa, Pawnee, and Osage.

options.label: C
options.text: Apache, Iroquois, Chippewa, Pawnee, and Lakota.

options.label: D
options.text: Navajo, Sioux, Lakota, Pawnee, and Osage.
